runs.text: Tell students that a possessive noun shows ownership. Explain that to show one person or thing owns something, add apostrophe
(s). To show more than one person or thing owns something, add an apostrophe (s). Add
to an irregular plural noun that does not end in

. Then use each word in a sentence to distinguish singular from plural nouns.
. Have students form the possessive for each one and then say and write a sentence for it.
(Add words with skills your students need to review.)
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you see thats different in these two words? Why?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.

Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Remind students that possessive nouns show ownership. Review how to form possessives using
. Then use each word in a sentence to distinguish singular from plural nouns.
. Model how to form the possessive for each word. Guide students in reading each word.
Have students form the possessive for each word. Have students make a sentence with each word.
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
Which sounds do you hear in
? (/g/ /a/ /v/)? Which letters do you see? (g-a-v-e) English words dont end in the letter v. If you hear the v
sound at the end of the word, add the letter
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.

Create a card with an apostrophe or draw one on a sticky note. Use the apostrophe card and Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words. For additional clues, provide word meanings or use the word in a sentence.

to the end. What new word did you make?

Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.

Dictate the following words for students to spell:

. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
. Read the words and identify the possessive endings. Have students repeat. Remind students that possessive nouns show ownership and can be singular, plural, or irregular plural nouns.
, one at a time. Model how to read the new words formed. Identify each noun as singular or plural possessive. Use each word in a sentence.
(s). Guide students to read the words and identify each as singular or plural possessive.
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out the difference between singular and plural nouns and singular and plural possessive nouns.
Encourage students to look for possessive nouns while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.

Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.

Read, Build, Write: brought, contain, front, gave, inches, material, noun, ocean, strong, verb

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., An example of a noun is the word_____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.

Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
can be added to nouns to form possessive nouns. Display the words
. Have students identify each word as a singular or plural possessive noun and explain how they know.
. Model how to form the possessive noun for each word and tell if the noun is singular or plural.
Have students select two of the possessive nouns and write sentences for them.
This word describes a very sharp object.
Change the first two letters of knife to form a word that is the opposite of husband.
Add an ending to make wife a singular possessive noun.
Change one letter and move the apostrophe in wifes to make a plural possessive noun.
Replace one letter in wives to form a word that is the possessive plural of a very sharp object.
Replace two letters in knives to form the plural possessive form of life.
Read, Build, Write: brought, contain, front, gave, inches, material, noun, ocean, strong, verb
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
